attributes.title: Diverging Preferences of Economic Elites and Public Opinion on Immigration Policies: Evidence from Survey Experiments in Japan

q1.value: Diverging Preferences of Economic Elites and Public Opinion on Immigration Policies: Evidence from Survey Experiments in Japan

q2.value: Rieko Kage | Frances Rosenbluth | Seiki Tanaka

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Why do some countries accept more immigrants with temporary visas than others? One strand of scholars suggests that the pull factors from business interests explain more of the variation, while others emphasize the importance of public opinion. Departing from this dichotomy, we consider both factors at the same time in a systematic way and shed light on (1) differences within economic elites as well as within public opinion; and (2) overlapping preferences between economic elites and the general public over immigration policies. Ultimately, we aim to provide a better understanding of why some countries are more accepting of immigrants than are others.

q16.value: We propose to test the following main hypotheses: - Economic elites are more likely to favor the admission of foreign workers than low-skilled workers for whom they represent competition for jobs and wages. - Economic elites should favor accepting low-skilled foreign workers as cheap labor. - Middle and high level managers may oppose high-skilled foreign workers for ladder-track jobs for fear of merit-based evaluation in the place of firm practices already in place. - Economic elites in firms with more women employees are more likely to favor accepting foreign workers because they have already adapted to non-traditional labor practices. - Economic elites in firms with extensive overseas productions are more likely to favor foreign workers because foreign workers can be kept on a separate, non-competitive track. - Leaders of firms with labor shortages are more likely to favor admitting foreign workers. - Leaders of high-technology firms are less likely to favor admitting foreign workers.

q17.value: To test the hypotheses, we conduct corporate and public opinion surveys in Japan in December 2019 by using similar survey designs. To examine the main hypotheses, we embed a conjoint experiment in the surveys. We adopt forced-choice conjoint methods and the experiment is designed to gauge which attribute respondents are the most concerned with for immigration accommodation. More specifically, after showing a pair of hypothetical scenarios, we ask respondents which immigrant groups/workers they are more likely to accommodate/hire.

registration_responses.q1: Diverging Preferences of Economic Elites and Public Opinion on Immigration Policies: Evidence from Survey Experiments in Japan
registration_responses.q2: Rieko Kage | Frances Rosenbluth | Seiki Tanaka

attributes.title: To know the court is to love it? The effect of information and knowledge on judicial legitimacy

q1.value: To know the court is to love it? The effect of information and knowledge on judicial legitimacy

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Most people have strong opinions about courts: they punish too mildly and they are ‘out of touch with society’ (Roberts et al. 2003). In spite of these strong opinions there is widespread public ignorance about courts and the fundamental role that courts in in the rule of law (e.g. Van de Walle 2009; Hough and Park 2001). The obvious way to end ignorance is to provide people with more information to increase knowledge and eventually legitimacy. There is correlational evidence that more knowledge about courts coincides with confidence in courts at the state level (Benesh 2006) and the Supreme Court (Gibson and Caldeira 1998). This has led researchers to the conclude that ‘to know the Court is to love it’. But does increased knowledge about the justice system actually cause more support for the judiciary? And what kind of knowledge? The number of rigorous experiments to investigate these questions has been limited. Furthermore, older experiments have shown that deliberative polling (Roberts and Stalans 2000), or booklets (Mirrlees-Black, 2002) slightly improve attitudes towards criminal courts. However, these experiments are based on self-selected participants and not on random, representative, sample from the population. This limits the external validity of the these experiments. In this paper we address this dearth in the literature as follows. First, we use a survey-based experiment in a randomly drawn, representative, sample from the population of the Netherlands. Second, we use a longitudinal experimental design with measures of objective knowledge and perceived legitimacy at three moments in time. This allows us to probe long term effects, so not only the effect right after the experiment. Furthermore, we can obtain a longitudinal dataset by fielding a survey at three points in time: we use a pre-test survey (T1) to measure of legitimacy and knowledge three months prior to the experimental treatment. This way we employ a within-subject design while limiting the risk of test-effects. At T2 a survey experiment is conducted and subsequently knowledge and legitimacy are measured. A post-test survey (T3) one month after the experiment will be used to establish if the potential effect is durable.

q16.value: H1) Providing information about the justice system leads to higher levels of objective knowledge about the justice system. H2) Providing information about the justice system leads to higher levels of diffuse support (institutional legitimacy). H3) Providing information about the justice system leads to higher levels of specific support (support for judges in a specific case) H4) The effect will be more pronounced amongst individuals with relatively low levels of knowledge prior to the experiment.

q17.value: Repeated-measures ANOVA to test for changes over time (within subjects) and whether these changes over time significantly interact with the treatment (between subjects).

attributes.title: Restoring the Rule of Law After Civil War: A Field Experiment on Security and Justice Provision in Rural Colombia

attributes.title: Pre-Analysis Plan for Summer 2018 Immigration Experiment

q1.value: Pre-Analysis Plan for Summer 2018 Immigration Experiment

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: The experiment has seven steps: 1. We recruited voters to join an online survey panel. The voters were recruited via mail sent to the address at which they were registered to vote. This mail directed them to an online survey. 2. Among voters who completed the baseline survey, we randomly assigned voters to receive a long treatment conversation on immigration, a short treatment conversation on immigration or a placebo conversation. This random assignment took place at the household level, within blocks defined by household size and the first factor from factor analysis on a number of pre-treatment covariates about immigration. We dropped voters who were above the 90th percentile within the voter’s stateon both of two indices formed by the policy and prejudice items, respectively, as these voters should not see any persuasive effects due to a ceiling effect. This was approximately 5% of voters in pilot data. 3. The partner group implements the canvass, delivering either a persuasion conversation or a placebo conversation depending on the voter’s random assignment. Voters do not realize the canvassing is connected to the survey in any way. 4. We invite voters who were successfully reached (compliers) to take a follow-up survey. 5. We analyze the results of this survey to assess the effects of the conversations. In particular, we compare the views of voters who received the immigration conversations to those who received the placebo conversations. How we plan to do so is described below. 6. We will assess how long-lasting the persuasive effects of the canvass are by continuing to send follow-up survey waves.

q16.value: Does the canvass decrease anti-immigrant prejudice and increase support for immigrant rights? Which canvass is more effective?

attributes.title: Partisanship, Issue Position, and Social Trust in a Multiparty System

q1.value: Partisanship, Issue Position, and Social Trust in a Multiparty System

q2.value: Lenka Hrbková | Vlastimil Havlík | Petr Voda

q5.value: Funded by the Czech Science Foundation (GA17-09296S)

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This study tests effects of partisanship and attitude towards immigration on social trust. The experiment builds on the game-based experimental research on affective polarization set in the context of Western Europe, Latin America and the USA (Carlin and Love 2018; Iyengar and Westwood 2015; Martini and Torcal 2019; Westwood et al. 2018). We want to extend this research tradition with a study set in a post-communist Central and Eastern European context of the Czech Republic where there is a fragmented party system, low levels of party identification, and volatile voting behavior. Apart from political parties, we also test the role of immigration attitudes on affective polarization, another a potentially divisive and polarizing factors identified in a previous experimental study (http://egap.org/registration/5779). The proposed study intends to test the effects of partisanship and issue position on social trust in a modified trust game (Westwood et al. 2018). Our approach innovates the game design, enabling trust game in a multipartism without limiting the number of parties included in the experiment to the major parties in the system. Such practice has been usual in previous research which applied trust game as a measure of partisan trust in multiparitsms (Carlin and Love 2018; Martini and Torcal 2019; Westwood et al. 2018).This way, we can capture the complex nature of party based polarization in a fragmented multiparty system.

q16.value: If partisanship works as a socially polarizing factor with the potential of reducing social trust, then we assume that: H1a. Player 2 being a supporter of the same party as Player 1 increases the amount of money allocated to Player 2 by Player 1 in a trust game, all else equal. H1b. Player 2 being a supporter of the Player 1´s least preferred party decreases the amount of money allocated to Player 2 by Player 1 in a trust game, all else equal. H1c. Player 2 being a supporter of any other party (apart from Player 1´s most and least preferred party) changes the amount of money allocated to Player 2 by Player 1 in a trust game depending on the level of sympathy Player 1 feels towards Player 2´s preferred party, all else equal. If attitudes towards immigration work as a polarizing force with the potential to reduce social trust across citizens with opposing attitudes: H2a. Player 2 having the same attitude on immigration as Player 1 increases the amount of money allocated to Player 2 by Player 1 in a trust game, all else equal. H2b. Player 2 having the opposite attitude towards immigration than Player 1 decreases the amount of money allocated to Player 2 by Player 1 in a trust game, all else equal. Social identity theory (Tajfel and Turner 1979) suggests that ingroup favoritism and outgroup aversion may originate from a mere division of individuals into groups. If the above mentioned effects are at work due to the nature of partisan bias or bias against opposing immigration attitudes then the effects should be larger than effects of membership in a random non-political group. Therefore we expect that H3a. Player 2 being a member of a same random nonpolitical group as Player 1 will not have effect on the amount of money allocated to Player2 by Player 1 in a trust game compared to congruence in party preference or congruence in attitude towards immigration. H3b. Player 2 being a member of a different random nonpolitical group as Player 1 will not have effect on the amount of money allocated to Player 2 by Player one in a trust game compared to Payer 2´s preference of Player 1´s least preferred political party or having opposing attitude towards immigration then Player 1.

q17.value: The study is based on an experimental survey implementing a multiple round of modified trust game (as in Iyengar and Westwood 2015; Westwood et al. 2018). The study will be conducted on a nonprobability sample representative on age, gender, education, type of settlement, and region. The data will be collected by a research company (Focus). In the trust game, all subjects will be assigned the role of Player 1. They will be given a 100 CZK endowment and asked about how much money they would allocate to a randomly chosen Player 2. Subjects will play repeated trust game, each round will be played with a different (fictious) Player 2. Subjects will have one piece of information about each Player 2. Fitst two rounds will not be experimental per se. In the first round subject will allocate money to a completely anonymous Player 2. The next eight rounds will be experimental. Subjects will decide about the amount of money to be sent to Players 2 characterized by information: - Party preference (subject´s most preferred party, subject´s least preferred party, or any other randomly generated party) - Attitude towards immigration (pro-immigration attitude, neutral attitude, ani-immigration attitude) - Membership in one of two artificially created groups of respondents based on colors, all (blue group or green group) The hypotheses will be analyzed in regression models enabling clustered standard errors. Negative binomial regression with fixed effects for individual subjects will be used, the dependent variable will be operationalized as the amount of money allocated to Player 2. The experimental conditions (i.e. attributes of Player 2s) will be used as independent variables. For better robustness of results, a Tobit regression model will be employed as well. In additional models, the control for party sympathy will be included.

registration_responses.q1: Partisanship, Issue Position, and Social Trust in a Multiparty System
registration_responses.q2: Lenka Hrbková | Vlastimil Havlík | Petr Voda
registration_responses.q5: Funded by the Czech Science Foundation (GA17-09296S)

q5.value: I wish to thank Elizabeth Carlson, Thad Dunning, James Fearon, Guy Grossman, Angelo Izama, Evan Lieberman, Nikos Nikiforakis, Laura Paler, Ernesto Reuben, Amanda Robinson, Leah Rosenzweig,, and Jeremy Weinstein for their feedback on earlier versions and components of the research design, and to Shem Yuda for assistance with piloting

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In many African countries, there exists an education gap between Christians and Muslims, where Muslims have less schooling on average than Christians, as measured by years of schooling and literacy among adults, and school attendance status of children. The magnitude of this gap is increasing with the share of the local population that is Muslim. Previous work has shown that this latter phenomenon is not fully explained by poverty, beliefs about the returns to education, displacement of formal schooling by religious schooling, or access/distance to school. In this pre-analysis plan, I describe a lab-in-the-field experiment designed to measure the social benefits and costs of schooling. Specifically, I aim to measure social norms about the appropriateness of completing various levels of school, and how these norms differ across Christians and Muslims in Muslim minority and Muslim majority areas. This exercise is conceptually similar to measuring beliefs about the economic returns to education, but here I aim to estimate returns to education, which hinge critically on an individual's beliefs about normative beliefs about schooling. To do so, respondents will be monetarily incentivized to guess, among a religiously homogeneous/heterogeneous session of community members, the modal response of the degree of social acceptability of completing various levels of school. I expect that there will be higher social returns to schooling (lower modal acceptability of dropping out) among Muslims in Muslim minority areas as compared to Muslims in Muslim majority areas. I also expect there will be greater differences in social returns to schooling between Christians and Muslims in the Muslim majority areas, compared to the difference between Christians and Muslims in the Muslim minority areas. I also propose a set of dictator games designed to measure the extent to which social sanctioning varies within and across religious groups, as well as how minority status affects social sanctioning.

registration_responses.q5: I wish to thank Elizabeth Carlson, Thad Dunning, James Fearon, Guy Grossman, Angelo Izama, Evan Lieberman, Nikos Nikiforakis, Laura Paler, Ernesto Reuben, Amanda Robinson, Leah Rosenzweig,, and Jeremy Weinstein for their feedback on earlier versions and components of the research design, and to Shem Yuda for assistance with piloting

attributes.title: Ranked Conjoint Experiments: Design and Application

q1.value: Ranked Conjoint Experiments: Design and Application

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We introduce fully randomized ranked conjoint experiments as a novel experimental design. We propose a simple extension of standard choice-based or rating-based conjoint designs, and evaluate its properties with respect to efficiency, practicality, estimation, and inference. We hypothesize that ranked-choice designs are superior on these properties than forced-choice designs.

q16.value: H1: Total survey length is shorter under ranked-choice than under forced-choice designs. H2: Attrition and survey satisficing are less under ranked-choice than under forced-choice designs. H3: Estimation efficiency is greater under ranked-choice than under forced-choice designs. H4: Ranked-choice designs better uncover transitive preferences than forced-choice designs. H5: Ranked-choice designs better satisfy the independence of irrelevant alternatives assumption than forced-choice designs.

q17.value: Study 1 randomly assigns subjects to either completing a series of forced-choice conjoint tasks or a series of ranked-choice conjoint tasks, and we compare treatment groups with respect to key outcome measures: survey length and response time, attrition and response quality, estimation efficiency, and AMCE’s and predicted probabilities. Study 2 consists of 12 treatment arms where subjects complete ranked-choice conjoint tasks, but a first randomly assigned to a varying number of profiles per task, then to a varying number of attributes per profile. We test whether inclusion of additional profiles affects rank orders provided, as well as optimal conjoint matrix complexity/size.

q23.value: The project will be submitted the Institutional Review Board (IRB) shortly.

attributes.title: Ownership and Indirect Taxation: A Field and Survey Experiment

q1.value: Ownership and Indirect Taxation: A Field and Survey Experiment

q2.value: Brandon de la Cuesta | Lucy Martin | Helen Milner | Daniel Nielson

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This project develops and tests a theory linking psychological ownership over government budgets to citizens’ demands on leaders. There are many reasons to expect citizens’ ownership over government revenues to vary even conditional on revenue source, and these differences may help to explain when citizens will punish poor performance. We argue that citizens with high psychological ownership over the government budget will have higher expectations for how much they should benefit from government spending. Poor government performance generates negative emotions in citizens with high expectations, and these negative emotions are then alleviated through sanctioning those responsible. Psychological ownership therefore increases the expressive benefits citizens receive from punishment, making them more willing to pay to punish. We also argue that psychological ownership is malleable, and that as a result it is possible to increase citizens’ sense of ownership over windfall revenues. Lab experiments, conducted by the authors in Uganda, provide encouraging evidence in favor of the ownership hypothesis, and suggesting that it might be possible to manipulate ownership over windfall revenues and, through higher ownership, increase accountability pressures for aid and oil, more work needs to be done. Lab experiments are conducted in a very abstract setting, and it is not clear whether the same dynamics will hold outside of the lab. This research design lays out a plan to test the ownership mechanism outside of the lab, focusing on whether it is possible to increase citizens’ willingness to take costly political actions by increasing their ownership over windfall revenues. This experiment will be carried out using a large sample of Ugandans in 2018.

q16.value: Our pre-analysis plan lays out three tiers of hypotheses. The most critical hypothesis is that our ownership treatments, which are designed to encourage subjects to think of non-tax revenues as their own personal revenue, will induce both higher levels of ownership and a greater willingness to take costly political action. We also have a set of information treatments that we expect to have positive, but smaller, effects on both ownership and willingness to take costly political actions.

q17.value: We have 7 treatments: pure control, aid information, oil information, tax information, aid ownership, and tax ownership. Respondents are randomly assigned to one of the treatments; after the treatment prompt is given during the survey, all respondents are asked a set of outcome questions in which they have the opportunity to take one or more costly political actions (such as sending a message to a government official, or sending an SMS in order to get more information). We then estimate the effects of the treatments on the outcomes, as well as three potential mechanisms: ownership, information, and corruption. All comparisons will be done using OLS with and without block and enumerator fixed effects. A third specification designed to increase precision will include pre-treatment covariates that predict our outcome measures. Due to precision improvements associated with blocking and the importance of some pre-treatment covariates in pilot data, this is our preferred specification. All outcome measures will also be considered in an inverse covariance-weighted index.

registration_responses.q1: Ownership and Indirect Taxation: A Field and Survey Experiment
registration_responses.q2: Brandon de la Cuesta | Lucy Martin | Helen Milner | Daniel Nielson
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: This project develops and tests a theory linking psychological ownership over government budgets to citizens’ demands on leaders. There are many reasons to expect citizens’ ownership over government revenues to vary even conditional on revenue source, and these differences may help to explain when citizens will punish poor performance. We argue that citizens with high psychological ownership over the government budget will have higher expectations for how much they should benefit from government spending. Poor government performance generates negative emotions in citizens with high expectations, and these negative emotions are then alleviated through sanctioning those responsible. Psychological ownership therefore increases the expressive benefits citizens receive from punishment, making them more willing to pay to punish. We also argue that psychological ownership is malleable, and that as a result it is possible to increase citizens’ sense of ownership over windfall revenues. Lab experiments, conducted by the authors in Uganda, provide encouraging evidence in favor of the ownership hypothesis, and suggesting that it might be possible to manipulate ownership over windfall revenues and, through higher ownership, increase accountability pressures for aid and oil, more work needs to be done. Lab experiments are conducted in a very abstract setting, and it is not clear whether the same dynamics will hold outside of the lab. This research design lays out a plan to test the ownership mechanism outside of the lab, focusing on whether it is possible to increase citizens’ willingness to take costly political actions by increasing their ownership over windfall revenues. This experiment will be carried out using a large sample of Ugandans in 2018.
registration_responses.q16: Our pre-analysis plan lays out three tiers of hypotheses. The most critical hypothesis is that our ownership treatments, which are designed to encourage subjects to think of non-tax revenues as their own personal revenue, will induce both higher levels of ownership and a greater willingness to take costly political action. We also have a set of information treatments that we expect to have positive, but smaller, effects on both ownership and willingness to take costly political actions.
registration_responses.q17: We have 7 treatments: pure control, aid information, oil information, tax information, aid ownership, and tax ownership. Respondents are randomly assigned to one of the treatments; after the treatment prompt is given during the survey, all respondents are asked a set of outcome questions in which they have the opportunity to take one or more costly political actions (such as sending a message to a government official, or sending an SMS in order to get more information). We then estimate the effects of the treatments on the outcomes, as well as three potential mechanisms: ownership, information, and corruption. All comparisons will be done using OLS with and without block and enumerator fixed effects. A third specification designed to increase precision will include pre-treatment covariates that predict our outcome measures. Due to precision improvements associated with blocking and the importance of some pre-treatment covariates in pilot data, this is our preferred specification. All outcome measures will also be considered in an inverse covariance-weighted index.

attributes.title: How Voters Use Contextual Information to Reward and Punish: Credit Claiming, Legislative Performance, and Democratic Accountability

q1.value: How Voters Use Contextual Information to Reward and Punish: Credit Claiming, Legislative Performance, and Democratic Accountability

q2.value: Alan Gerber | Eric M. Patashnik | Patrick Tucker

q9.value: Registration is prior to any research activities, but we did field a previous experiment using a similar design.

q15.value: Previous research finds that citizens are responsive to the act of legislator credit-claiming, but that they are largely insensitive to the dollar amount of appropriations advertised. The mechanics behind this phenomenon is less understood. Citizens’ insensitivity may be due to innumeracy or a lack of meaningful information that puts credit claiming into an appropriate context. We replicate and extend a previous design by Grimmer et al. (2015) that experimentally manipulates the relative size of a credit claiming advertisement. That is, we manipulate whether a grant is smaller or larger than the average federal grant. In this way, we are able to determine if citizens are responsive to the relative size of credit claiming project.

q16.value: H1. Grant Amount Hypothesis: The amount of money announced by the legislator in the experimental vignette will not be significantly related to the subject’s evaluation of the legislator. H2. Context of Grant Hypothesis: The relative size of the grant announced by the legislator in the experimental vignette will be positively related to the subject’s evaluation of the legislator H3. Asymmetric Context of Grant Hypothesis: Being informed that a grant is less than average will significantly reduce the citizen’s evaluation of the legislator, but being informed that the grant is greater than average will have no statistically distinct effect on the evaluation of the legislator.

q17.value: To test H1, we will assign approximately ½ of our sample to a pure replication of the Grimmer et al. (2015) study whereby we manipulate the dollar amount of a grant secured by a legislator. Respondents will then evaluate the legislator on a 0 to 100 favorability scale. We then conduct a simple linear regression to test for an effect of the grant amount on the evaluation. To test H2, we randomly assign the other ½ of our sample to be informed about the context of the grant. Here we manipulate whether the grant is a certain percentage less than or greater than the average grant secured. Respondents then evaluate the legislator on the favorability scale. We regress that evaluation onto a continuous measure for the grant context variable. To test H3, we reclassify the grant context variable into three categories: less than average, average, and greater than average. Treating average as the baseline category, we regress the evaluation on this categorical variable. We expect the less than average category will have a significant and negative effect on the evaluation, but the greater than average category will have an effect that is not distinguishable from zero.

q25.value: Umbrella Protocol for IRB exemption initially approved 12/02/2013

attributes.title: The Political Consequences of Violence: Empathy and Action amidst Conflict

q1.value: The Political Consequences of Violence: Empathy and Action amidst Conflict

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Although war is popularly associated with destruction, recent research suggests war can have generative effects, particularly as it relates to citizen civic engagement. From Africa to Latin America, individual exposure to criminal and political violence is positively associated with future civic participation (Blattman 2009; Shewfelt 2009; Bellows and Miguel 2009; Annan, et al. 2011; Bateson 2012; Cassar, Grosjean and Whitt 2013; Bauer, et al. 2014; Ley-Gutierrez 2014; De Luca and Verpoorten 2015). Despite expectations that victims of violence will disengage from civic life out of fear or trauma, the positive association between exposure to violence and future civic action is notably persistent. Why this relationship persists, however, is less clear. What explains the positive relationship between exposure to violence and civic engagement? The present study uses an experimental module of questions on a nationally representative survey in Mexico to test hypotheses about how indirect exposure to violence, such as through media reports, shapes individuals' likelihood of future civic engagement. Specifically, the study analyzes how priming respondents to feel empathy for victims of violence may shape their interest in participating in civic activities. The role of empathy for victims of violence is tested because qualitative research conducted during the year prior to this survey experiment pointed toward empathy as a driving force of the relationship between individual indirect exposure to violence and future civic engagement. This survey experiment thus reflects an inductively-generated theory of the relationship between exposure to violence and civic engagement.

q16.value: In my primary analysis, I employ one main outcome variable, civic engagement. I take civic engagement to mean individual and collective actions that aim to address issues of public concern (APA). Since civic engagement may include more or less explicitly political actions or may engage political institutions to varying degrees, I disaggregate this concept into three categories of civic life: political participation, community engagement, and anti-violence civic engagement. The outcome is measured as the respondent's reported level of interest in these three categories of civic engagement. The hypotheses (below) expect that individuals who feel empathy for victims of violence will express greater interest in participating in all three categories of civic engagement than individuals that do not feel empathy for victims. H1: Respondents primed to feel empathy for victims of violence will express greater interest in political participation than those whose empathy is primed to be depressed. H2: Respondents primed to feel empathy for victims of violence will express greater interest in community engagement than those whose empathy is primed to be depressed. H3: Respondents primed to feel empathy for victims of violence will express greater interest in anti-violence civic engagement than those whose empathy is primed to be depressed. Since empathy is generated by shared similarities and the ability to imagine oneself in the shoes of another, it is possible that the treatments may have a unique effect for respondents who are direct victims (meaning either they or a loved one experienced violence first-hand). H4 hypothesizes: H4: Compared to other respondents primed to feel empathy, victim respondents will express equal or greater interest in the three categories of civic engagement. H5: Compared to other respondents in the control group, victim respondents will express greater interest in the three categories of civic engagement. H6: Compared to other respondents for whom empathy is depressed, victim respondents will express greater interest in the three categories of civic engagement.

q17.value: The survey experiment includes two treatment groups and one control, to which respondents will be randomly assigned. All respondents read a brief news-style report about a hypothetical case of violence. Prior to reading that report, Treatment Group (A) will be given a standard "low-empathy" prime, which instructs them to read the report as objectively as possible. Treatment Group (B) will be given a standard "high-empathy" prime, which instructs them to imagine themselves in the place of the victim. The control group receives no special instruction. After reading the report, respondents are asked to express their interest in a number of civic activities. The civic engagement questions are followed by demographic questions that are not likely to change with treatment: age, gender, SES, and victimization status. For my main analyses, I will use difference-in-means tests. I will use OLS regression to analyze the conditional average treatment effects for respondents who report being victims of a violent crime.
